Articles.Content:
So I decided I wanted to have a go at 3D modelling again (after a very poor attempt when I was like, 12), and I've made the SpaceLab pallet. Of course, my next step is to UV Unwrap and texture, but when I try to unwrap it, I find that some of the faces get really distorted (pictured below). I was wondering if anyone knew how to get around that?

Here's my current progress:

And here's the UV issue I was talking about:

Well there are a few different things you can do. First off I would recommend unwrapping everything onto a Color Grid/UV Grid instead of a single-color image or a transparent layer. This screenshot of my old Ariane 5 illustrates what I mean.

Doing it this way allows you to manually resize the UV islands along the X,Y and Z axis' to get rid of any squeeze or stretch that might have occured during unwrapping. Set the viewport shading to "Texture" and see the results in real time. Your end goal should be to have all the squares on the Color Grid/UV Grid appear as, well, squares on your model.

 There are also quite a few addons for Blender that does a pretty good job at figuring out how to unwrap the mesh properly. Lastly you can try different unwrap methods, like "Project" From View" and so on. Going into Orthograpic view and unwrapping using "Project From View" is very useful for flat areas on your models.

Edited June 18, 2016 by liquidhype

6 hours ago, liquidhype said:

Well there are a few different things you can do. First off I would recommend unwrapping everything onto a Color Grid/UV Grid instead of a single-color image or a transparent layer. This screenshot of my old Ariane 5 illustrates what I mean.

Doing it this way allows you to manually resize the UV islands along the X,Y and Z axis' to get rid of any squeeze or stretch that might have occured during unwrapping. Set the viewport shading to "Texture" and see the results in real time. Your end goal should be to have all the squares on the Color Grid/UV Grid appear as, well, squares on your model.

 There are also quite a few addons for Blender that does a pretty good job at figuring out how to unwrap the mesh properly. Lastly you can try different unwrap methods, like "Project" From View" and so on. Going into Orthograpic view and unwrapping using "Project From View" is very useful for flat areas on your models.

Thanks for the tips! With regards to Blender plugins, do you have any you'd recommend?

Those octagonal details might be better added via texturing rather than meshes, but you can always test both options out later.

For uv unwrapping, have you marked seams? It looks like you just selected "smart uv project".

For testing, keep those faces you have highlighted, and just select the basic unwrap option and see how they get unwrapped. There are two options that come up on the left pane "conformal or angle based". See how they change your uv island. There is another check box that say something like keep proportions (I'm out of town so going off memory)

3 minutes ago, cxg2827 said:

Those octagonal details might be better added via texturing rather than meshes, but you can always test both options out later.

For uv unwrapping, have you marked seams? It looks like you just selected "smart uv project".

For testing, keep those faces you have highlighted, and just select the basic unwrap option and see how they get unwrapped. There are two options that come up on the left pane "conformal or angle based". See how they change your uv island. There is another check box that say something like keep proportions (I'm out of town so going off memory)

I'll try those out, but I don't really understand what the seams do. All the wiki guides on UV unwrapping are really outdated, and the UI has changed a lot too, so they're hard to use for a beginner. I'll see if I can find a YouTube guide or something I guess

Think of seams like on a article of clothing. It's the edges that get stitched to create the completed piece.

When your mark the seams (ctrl+e) (mark seam) you tell blender that you want this group of meshes to be their own island. Without seams you can get get funky distortions depending on your uv workflow.

Take a look at uv seam videos, as those can explain it better visually.
Okay, will do. Thanks for the help!
